Technical Assistance Report 
 
Project Number: 46141 
Research and Development Technical Assistance (RDTA) 
December 2012 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Assisting the Central Asia Regional Economic 
Cooperation Institute Knowledge Program (Phase 1) 
 
 
The views expressed herein are those of the consultant and do not necessarily represent those of ADB‘s 
members, Board of Directors, Management, or staff, and may be preliminary in nature.

ABBREVIATIONS 
 
  ADB  –  Asian Development Bank 
  CAREC  –  Central Asia Regional Economic Cooperation 
  SKF  –  strategic knowledge framework 
  TA  –  technical assistance 
 
TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE CLASSIFICATION 
 
Type  –  Research and development technical assistance (RDTA) 
Targeting classification  –  General intervention 
Sector (subsectors)  –  Multisector (economic and public affairs management; public 
administration; transport management and policies; energy 
sector development; industry and trade sector development) 
Themes (subthemes)  –  Regional cooperation and integration (trade and investments, 
other regional public goods); economic growth (widening access 
to markets and economic opportunities); private sector 
development; capacity development (client relations, network, 
and partnership development) 
Location (impact)  –  Rural (low); urban (low); national (high); regional (high) 
 
NOTE 
 
In this report, "$" refers to US dollars.  
 
 
Vice-President  X. Zhao, Operations 1 
Director General  K. Gerhaeusser, Central and West Asia Department (CWRD) 
Director  V. Tan, Regional Cooperation and Operations Coordination Division, CWRD 
   
Team leader  L. Wu, Advisor, CWRD  
Team members  N. Benizano, Operations Assistant 
C. Delos Santos, Associate Programs Analyst, CWRD 
T. Hayakawa, Economist, CWRD 
S. Narvasa, Senior Operations Assistant, CWRD 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
In  preparing  any  country  program  or  strategy,  financing  any  project,  or  by  making  any 
designation of or reference to a particular territory or geographic area in this document, the 
Asian Development Bank does not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other status 
of any territory or area.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The Central Asia Regional Economic Cooperation (CAREC) Institute was established in 
2006 as the knowledge institution of and for the CAREC program.1 CAREC 2020, which lays out 
the strategic vision and operational directions for the CAREC program, identifies the CAREC 
Institute as one of its seven operational priorities, and calls on the institute to provide the 
required analytical work and strengthen stakeholder capacities to support the achievement of 
CAREC‗s  strategic  goals  of  expanding  trade  and  improving  competitiveness.2 Further,  the 
strategic knowledge framework (SKF), 2013–2017 for the institute was endorsed by the senior 
officials‘ meeting held in June 2012. The SKF has three components: knowledge generation 
(research), knowledge services (capacity building), and knowledge management. The objective 
is to build the CAREC Institute into a leading knowledge institution on economic cooperation in 
the region. In particular, the institute will (i) sharpen its focus on regional, multisector, and 
common sector issues pertinent to CAREC; (ii) integrate knowledge generation, services, and 
management for effectiveness; and (iii) form strategic alliances with regional institutions and 
networks.3  
 
2.  Since  the  institute‘s  founding,  ADB  has  provided  secretariat  support  and  technical 
assistance (TA).4 After the adoption of CAREC 2020 in November 2011, consultation with 
CAREC countries on ways forward for the institute and concrete measures to implement the 
SKF has been held, including the senior officials‘ meeting held in June 2012 and a special 
national focal point meeting held in September 2012. On these occasions, the CAREC countries 
endorsed ADB‘s TA support for the CAREC Institute for knowledge generation, services, and 
management, to be built on  past TA support. The design and monitoring framework is in 
Appendix 1.  
 
II.  ISSUES 
3.  The CAREC program is a key mechanism for economic cooperation in the CAREC 
region. Since 2001, significant progress has been achieved, especially in the priority areas of 
transport and trade facilitation, energy, and trade policy, as evidenced by a properly functioning 
institutional framework for policy dialogue and decision making, as well as investments totaling 
over $19 billion to date. However, much remains to be done.  
 
4.  A key challenge facing the CAREC countries is to transform transport corridors into 
economic corridors. As rehabilitating six key CAREC transport corridors has progressed rapidly, 
the issue of how to use these roads and railways to maximum effect in terms of economic and 
social  development  is  gaining  urgency.  This  is  an  issue  which  transcends  single  sector 
capability and responsibility, and the width and depth of the issue are also beyond the purview 
                                                
1  Founded in 2001, CAREC is a partnership of 10 countries for regional economic cooperation—Afghanistan, 
Azerbaijan, the People‘s Republic of China, Kazakhstan, the Kyrgyz Republic, Mongolia, Pakistan, Tajikistan, 
Turkmenistan, and Uzbekistan—and six multilateral institutions: the Asian Development Bank (ADB), European 
Bank for Reconstruction and Development, International Monetary Fund, Islamic Development Bank, United 
Nations Development Programme, and the World Bank. ADB has served as the CAREC secretariat since 2001.  
2  ADB. 2012. CAREC 2020: A Strategic Framework for the Central Asia Regional Economic Cooperation Program, 
2011–2020. Manila. 
3  ADB‘s Vice-President for Operations 1 provided concept clearance for the technical assistance (TA) on 12 
September 2012. The TA first appeared in the business opportunities section of ADB‘s website on 7 September 
2012.  
4  ADB. 2006. Technical Assistance for Capacity Development for Regional Cooperation in CAREC Participating 
Countries, Phase I. Manila (TA 6375-REG; $990,000); ADB. 2008. Technical Assistance for the Central Asia 
Regional Economic Cooperation Institute, 2009–2012. Manila (TA 6488-REG; $5,000,000).

2   
of a single country. Similarly, no mechanism exists to date within the CAREC program for 
coping with this new challenge. Thus, better understanding of an economic corridor needs to be 
developed with respect to effective approaches, key issues, and appropriate policy measures 
and required investments.    
 
5.  To  improve  the  competitiveness  of  CAREC  countries,  further  progress  is  needed 
towards  free  movement  of  goods  and  people  across  borders.  While  past  assistance  and 
cooperation  in  CAREC  has  tended  to  be  single-sector  based  (e.g.,  customs  cooperation), 
further  progress  in  cross-border  trade  facilitation  will  require  multisector  coordination  and 
cooperation, both within a country and between neighboring countries. Within a country, future 
policy measures will likely involve multiple sectors and overarching policies, both at the border 
and behind the border. Among bordering countries, coordination in implementing effective policy 
measures will become critical. These ―second-generation‖ cooperation measures will require 
new insight, new knowledge, solutions, and new policy tools and measures, supported by 
appropriate mechanisms to facilitate the achievement of concrete progress on the ground.  
 
6.  The CAREC countries are strategically located across Eurasia, and events in the region 
could have significant impact on these countries. For example, the formation and development 
of the common economic space, which would integrate not only product markets but also capital 
and labor markets in several countries including some CAREC countries, would have a regional 
impact. Such region-wide issues would need to be studied for the benefit of CAREC member 
countries.  
 
7.  New challenges are also emerging in the traditional CAREC priority areas of transport, 
energy, trade policy, and trade facilitation. For example, while rebuilding the roads and railways 
along six CAREC transport corridors remains a key task, identifying and implementing cost-
effective  ways  of  maintaining  those  roads  already  rehabilitated  is  becoming  urgent.  With 
physical connectivity improved, road safety is becoming increasingly an issue as it directly 
impacts on people‘s lives and livelihood. Similarly, sector issues such as energy efficiency that 
are common across several CAREC countries are gaining importance.    
 
8.  Further mainstreaming CAREC  into the  national  development  agenda  and fostering 
stronger country ownership is fundamental, as further progress in economic cooperation in the 
region can only be achieved if the concepts, principles, and benefits of regional cooperation are 
internalized into the decision-making process of the individual CAREC countries. Thus, the 
provision of quality knowledge products and services which provide the analytical underpinnings 
of regional cooperation processes, their costs and benefits, and the best ways to implement 
them is critical to informed decision making on policy choices. It would also promote better 
understanding of the key challenges and evolving trends affecting the countries of the region, 
thus helping decision makers anticipate and craft appropriate responses. 
 
9.  As a knowledge institution, the CAREC Institute is mandated to address key regional, 
multisector, and common sector issues through its research and related activities. At the same 
time,  its  institutional  capacity  will  need  to  be  significantly  strengthened.  Key  issues  being 
deliberated by the countries for implementation include (i) establishing core staff; (ii) measures 
to strengthen the institute‘s governance structure, including academic advisory governance; 
(iii) reaching out to and establishing alliances with regional and nonregional stakeholders; and 
(iv) setting up an appropriate and effective monitoring and evaluation mechanism.  
 
10.  Lessons. Key lessons include quality issues associated with past research conducted 
by the institute, and the absence of research output dissemination, as discussed below.

3 
 
11.  Lack of focus. The past research agenda may have been significant in itself, but some 
lacked direct relevance to the CAREC program. The SKF endorsed in June 2012 emphasizes 
that the institute should focus on regional, multisector, and common sector issues pertinent to 
the CAREC program; this will result in the CAREC Institute becoming more focused. 
 
12.  Lack of knowledge management. Past ADB support focused on research and capacity 
building. Except for a website, no effort was made to meet the need for knowledge management 
in the CAREC program. The use of e-technology to package and process existing knowledge 
into products and services is one focus area of the TA. 
 
13.  Lack of networking. Similarly, little has resulted from past ADB support in terms of 
networking. In striving to become a knowledge bank, ADB has launched knowledge-related 
activities. In addition, institutions both within and outside the CAREC region have accumulated 
significant knowledge, experience, and lessons regarding policies and practices on economic 
cooperation. Forming networks and other alliances and exploring complementarities across 
institutions will be key tasks under the TA.  
 
14.  Lack of monitoring and evaluation. Going hand-in-hand with the above-mentioned 
shortcomings is the lack of effective monitoring and evaluation to provide early warnings and 
necessitate corrective measures. To be results-based, the CAREC Institute will treat effective 
monitoring and evaluation as a priority.  
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
15.  The impact will be the enhanced quality of regional cooperation in the context of CAREC 
2020.  The  outcome  will  be  enhanced  capacity  of  governments  and  other  stakeholders  in 
CAREC  countries  to  engage  in  regional  cooperation,  as  reflected  in  their  deepened 
understanding and improved skills; expertise; and capacity to plan, implement, and mainstream 
regional cooperation at the national and regional levels. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
16.  The TA will have four outputs. In implementing the outputs, the integrated approach 
emphasized in the SKF will be followed to achieve synergy among different lines of knowledge 
work and gain effectiveness.  
 
17.  Output 1: New knowledge. The CAREC Institute will plan, organize, and manage the 
conduct of research. First and foremost, a medium-term research agenda will be developed in 
line with the mandates given by CAREC 2020 and the SKF. Key areas of research may include 
(i)  policy  measures  and  investment  needs  for  specific  CAREC  corridors  which  would  be 
essential  in  transforming  a  transport  corridor  into  an  economic  corridor,  and  (ii)  further 
improvement  of  cross-border  trade  focusing  on  second-generation  policy  and  institutional 
measures and investment. Appropriate institutional mechanisms will be explored under both 
areas.  
 
18.  In conducting research, the institute will seek strategic alliances and association with 
regional and nonregional academic and research institutions and individuals, similar institutions 
of multilateral institution partners, as well as knowledge initiatives and programs within ADB,

4   
including the Asian Development Bank Institute. This approach will strengthen the CAREC 
Institute, benefit partner institutions, and facilitate the generation of new knowledge and the 
exchange of experiences and lessons in regional economic cooperation in Central Asia.  
 
19.  Output 2: Center of knowledge and information sources on regional cooperation. 
The CAREC Institute will provide the mechanisms by which knowledge about CAREC from 
multiple  sources  is  organized  in  a  user-friendly  way  that  facilitates  decision  making  and 
advances practical research activities. This will involve compiling and organizing existing data, 
information, and knowledge; transforming the data into knowledge products; and providing the 
means  for  easy  access  to  these  knowledge  products  by  policy  makers,  development 
practitioners,  academics  and  researchers,  and  civil  society.  The  institute  will  disseminate 
knowledge through appropriate means (e.g., CAREC website, conferences, workshops, and 
publications). The institute will also develop, maintain, and publish a database of research-
oriented institutions in the CAREC countries, with information on their affiliation, ownership, 
activities, areas of expertise, publications, and other relevant information. This database will 
facilitate regional exchange and knowledge sharing among CAREC countries. 
 
20.  Output 3: Platform for the exchange and dissemination of knowledge. Up-to-date, 
effective, and easily accessible means of disseminating knowledge and exchanging ideas and 
experiences could have significant impact on public awareness, academic research, and policy 
thinking on regional economic cooperation, through which new knowledge can germinate. The 
CAREC Institute in its next phase will pay particular attention to this area. The CAREC Institute 
will provide a platform for stakeholders to discuss and debate CAREC issues through seminars, 
conferences,  policy  dialogues,  and  roundtable  discussions.  Distinguished  speakers  and 
resource persons will be invited to these events. Networks of practitioners in transport and trade 
facilitation, energy, trade policy, and other sectors will be developed to promote knowledge 
exchange and collaboration between professionals and experts in CAREC countries. In addition, 
the institute will set up knowledge platforms to achieve accelerated connectivity in information 
and knowledge. Through electronic media, such platforms leverage the internet to share, create, 
and utilize knowledge among individuals, groups, and organizations. 
 
21.  Output 4: Strengthening institutional capacity. As the CAREC Institute strives to 
become a leading knowledge institution, considerable institutional strengthening will be needed. 
This will include establishing the institutional and academic governance structure, management, 
core staff, and advisory body. These are among the top issues for the countries to discuss, 
agree  upon,  and  prepare  to  establish.  In  addition,  an  effective  system for monitoring  and 
evaluation will need to be formulated and made operational, while taking into consideration the 
nature of the CAREC Institute as a knowledge institution. In the process, the institute will reach 
out to other knowledge-based initiatives both within and outside ADB for experience exchange 
and lessons.  
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
22.  The TA is estimated to cost $1.5 million equivalent, which will be financed on a grant 
basis by ADB‘s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-IV). Appendix 2 provides the details.  
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
23.  The TA will be implemented from December 2012 to December 2014. ADB will be the 
executing  agency,  with  the  Central  and  West  Asia  Regional  Cooperation  and  Operations 
Coordination  Division  as  the  focal  point  for  TA  administration,  including  coordinating  the

5 
recruitment and supervision of consultants. Guidance on the CAREC Institute work program will 
be  received  from,  and  regular  reporting  will  be  made  to,  the  existing  CAREC  institutional 
mechanism, which consists of sector coordination committees and senior officials‘ meetings and 
ministerial conferences. Coordination with the TA on capacity building of the CAREC Institute 
will be ensured.5  
 
24.  Implementing the TA will require 28 person-months of international consulting inputs 
from a research director and an institutional capacity building specialist, and 72 person-months 
of national consulting inputs from a research officer, a database and website analyst, and 
program  coordinator.  The  consultants‘  outline  terms  of  reference  are  in  Appendix  3.  The 
consultants will be engaged individually because of multiple skills required, in accordance with 
ADB‘s  Guidelines  on the  Use  of  Consultants (2010,  as  amended from  time to  time).  The 
consultants will be based in ADB headquarters. ADB staff will manage TA implementation with a 
senior staff member leading these efforts. Some office and telecommunications equipment may 
be procured pursuant to ADB‘s Procurement Guidelines (2010, as amended from time to time) 
and in coordination with the Office of Administrative Services and the Office of Information 
Systems and Technology.  
 
25.  Workshops,  conferences,  or  seminars  will  be  held  during  TA  implementation. 
Procurement of goods and other services under the TA will be made in accordance with the 
Procurement Guidelines. Disbursements under the TA will be done in accordance with ADB‘s 
Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from time to time).  
 
26.  Reports of TA outputs will be regularly submitted to the CAREC senior officials‘ meeting 
and ministerial conference, and posted on the CAREC website (www.carecprogram.org) and/or 
new website(s) created under the TA. The monitoring and evaluation system to be established 
under the TA will facilitate measurement of the TA outcome, and will be reported to the CAREC 
ministerial conference and disseminated widely on CAREC-related websites.  
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT’S DECISION  
27.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $1,500,000 on a grant basis 
for Assisting the Central Asia Regional Economic Cooperation Institute Knowledge Program 
(Phase 1), and hereby reports this action to the Board. 
                                                
5 ADB. Forthcoming. Technical Assistance for Central Asia Regional Economic Cooperation: Supporting Capacity 
Development Needs of CAREC 2020. Manila (programmed for 2012).

10  Appendix 3    
OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
1.   Under the supervision of Asian Development Bank (ADB) senior international staff who 
will oversee the technical assistance (TA) implementation, a total of about 28 person-months of 
international consultants and 72 person-months of national consultants will be engaged. These 
consultants will report to the senior international staff member from the Central and West Asia 
Department, who will act as team leader and supervise consultants‘ work.  
A.  International Consultants 
2.  Research  director  (24  person-months).  The  research  director  will  have  strong 
knowledge of regional cooperation and the key issues and subjects that need to be included in a 
knowledge program to support Central Asia Regional Economic Cooperation (CAREC) 2020,6 
and preferably have prior experience in managing a research program. Key deliverables will 
include  the  CAREC  Institute  medium-term  research  agenda,  agreed  arrangements  with 
collaborating  institutions,  and  regular  publications  summarizing  outcomes  of  the  institute‘s 
knowledge program. Responsibilities will include the following:   
(i)  assist in the overall management of the TA; 
(ii)  establish and make operational the policies, procedures, and work program of 
the CAREC Institute secretariat; 
(iii)  establish and maintain a network of collaborating research institutions that are 
qualified to provide knowledge products; 
(iv)  match the requirements of the research agenda with the capacities of potential 
partner institutions;  
(v)  conduct the assessment of medium- to long-term management and institutional 
structures for the CAREC Institute; 
(vi)  plan and lead the execution of knowledge events; 
(vii)  mobilize financial and technical resources for the institute;  
(viii)  implement,  monitor,  and  evaluate  the  progress  of  the  CAREC  Institute 
knowledge program, and prepare the requisite reports to the advisory body; 
(ix)  conduct research on any issues in the medium-term research agenda; 
(x)  carry out other related tasks as requested by the team leader; and 
(xi)  submit quarterly reports on the tasks performed during the assignment. 
 
3.  Institutional capacity building specialist  (4 person-months). The specialist should 
have broad experience in institutional capacity building with a strong emphasis on knowledge 
management. In  addition, the  specialist  should  have  a strong  background  of  working  with 
multilateral organizations. Prior knowledge of and working experience on CAREC issues are not 
required but preferable. The specialist will work intermittently as required, and will report directly 
to the ADB supervisor. Responsibilities will include the following:  
(i)  participate  in  preparing  overall  plans  for  strengthening  the  capacity  of  the 
CAREC Institute; 
(ii)  prepare draft documents for implementing the overall plans; 
(iii)  participate in activities including meetings and missions for implementing the 
overall plans;  
(iv)  advise on the research, capacity building, and knowledge management programs 
of the CAREC Institute; and 
(v)  carry out other related tasks as requested by the supervisor.  
                                                
6 ADB. 2012. CAREC 2020: A Strategic Framework for the Central Asia Regional Economic Cooperation Program, 
2011–2020. Manila.

ABBREVIATIONS 
 
  ADB  –  Asian Development Bank 
  CAREC  –  Central Asia Regional Economic Cooperation 
  SKF  –  strategic knowledge framework 
  TA  –  technical assistance 
 
TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE CLASSIFICATION 
 
Type  –  Research and development technical assistance (RDTA) 
Targeting classification  –  General intervention 
Sector (subsectors)  –  Multisector (economic and public affairs management; public 
administration; transport management and policies; energy 
sector development; industry and trade sector development) 
Themes (subthemes)  –  Regional cooperation and integration (trade and investments, 
other regional public goods); economic growth (widening access 
to markets and economic opportunities); private sector 
development; capacity development (client relations, network, 
and partnership development) 
Location (impact)  –  Rural (low); urban (low); national (high); regional (high) 
 
NOTE 
 
In this report, "$" refers to US dollars.  
 
 
Vice-President  X. Zhao, Operations 1 
Director General  K. Gerhaeusser, Central and West Asia Department (CWRD)

S. Narvasa, Senior Operations Assistant, CWRD 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
In  preparing  any  country  program  or  strategy,  financing  any  project,  or  by  making  any 
designation of or reference to a particular territory or geographic area in this document, the 
Asian Development Bank does not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other status
